question:
[FILL: Present a surprising experimental observation.
Example: 'A CRISPR knockout of transcription factor ZEB1 in A549 lung cancer cells unexpectedly INCREASED cell migration in a wound healing assay (2.1x faster closure vs. wild-type, p<0.001). ZEB1 is a known promoter of epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) and migration. How do you explain this paradox?']
ideal:
[FILL: Plausible mechanistic explanations.
Example: 'Possible explanations: 1) ZEB1 KO may derepress ZEB2, a paralog that can compensate and even hyperactivate EMT. 2) ZEB1 loss may trigger a collective migration phenotype (which is faster than mesenchymal single-cell migration) by restoring E-cadherin-mediated cell-cell junctions. 3) The wound healing assay measures 2D sheet migration, not invasion â€” ZEB1 KO cells may move faster as a sheet but lose 3D invasive capacity. The assay may not be measuring what the authors think.']

meta.step_role: Generate hypotheses to explain a paradoxical result
meta.what_cascades: If model can't generate plausible explanations, it can't design discriminating experiments
